page.title: 17Local History
page.content: William Penn lived at Warminghurst, to the southeast, and regularly walked across these fields to speak at Quaker meetings in the Friends Meeting House, the Blue Idol (1691), just north of Old House Farm. It had two tiny burial grounds, which were unlawful. Penn's daughter is buried there. Meetings were also held at Saucelands, a stone and mellow brick house near Coolham, probably 15th C. Before Coolham school was built, the farmer who lived at Saucelands let the Quakers teach local children in one room of the house. Horelands at Broadford Bridge was the house of Isaac Bongard, who worked for glassmakers Carre of Wisborough Green before glassmaking ended in 1618. Smuggling was rife in the 18th C. A smuggler's track ran from Gay Street to Coneyhurst, and Old House Lane is also known as Smuggler's Lane.
